title: License
text: R package (yusufHAIGermany) released MIT License. included data (sim_monthly, sim_weekly, sim_daily) synthetic derivatives publicly available data European Centre Disease Prevention Control (ECDC) Point Prevalence Survey Healthcare-Associated Infections Antimicrobial Use European Acute Care Hospitals, 2011–2012. Original data © European Centre Disease Prevention Control (ECDC), 2013. Licensed Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC 4.0). See https://creativecommons.org/licenses//4.0/ details. simulation transformation code used generate synthetic datasets (data-raw/simulate_hai_germany.R) © 2025 Yusuf Romadhon licensed MIT License.

title: Examples: Interactive Charts
text: shown Figure 1, monthly HAI composition clearly demonstrates persistent dominance UTI, represents largest monthly burden throughout entire observation period. HAP SSI next largest contributors, BSI CDI remain consistently lower stable, indicating limited variability month month. animation emphasises recurring seasonal pattern, infection categories increasing mid-year periods decreasing toward end cycle.
code:
monthly_long <- sim_monthly |> mutate(frame = format(as.Date(date), "%b %Y")) |> group_by(frame, hai) |> summarise(cases = sum(cases_month), .groups = "drop") p <- plot_ly( monthly_long, x = ~hai, y = ~cases, frame = ~frame, type = "bar", color = ~hai, hovertemplate = "%{frame}
%{x}: %{y:,.0f} cases" ) |> layout( barmode = "stack", xaxis = list(title = ""), yaxis = list(title = "Cases (monthly)"), title = list(text = "Monthly HAI Composition", x = 0, xanchor = "left"), margin = list(b = 110), #space for the caption annotations = list( list( text = "Figure 1: Stacked Monthly Totals by HAI.", xref = "paper", yref = "paper", x = 0, y = -0.20, showarrow = FALSE, align = "left" ) ) ) |> #plotly animation helpers animation_opts(frame = 800, transition = 0, redraw = FALSE) |> animation_slider(currentvalue = list(prefix = "Month: ")) |> animation_button(x = 1, xanchor = "right", y = 1.15) p

what: Weekly Intensity by HAI (Heatmap Faceted Yearly)
title: Examples: Interactive Charts
text: According Figure 2, UTI exhibits strongest weekly intensity across years, broad mid-year periods indicating consistently higher activity compared HAIs. HAP SSI show moderate, stable levels, BSI CDI remain consistently low limited weekly fluctuations. notable feature sharp UTI spike week 1 2012, visible brightest cell, followed return usual seasonal pattern.
code: wk <- sim_weekly |>   mutate(yr = year(as.Date(date)), week = iso_week) |>   group_by(yr, week, hai) |>   summarise(cases = sum(cases_week), .groups = "drop")  ggplot(wk, aes(x = week, y = hai, fill = cases)) +   geom_tile() +   scale_fill_viridis_c(label = scales::label_comma(), name = "Cases") +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(1, 13, 26, 39, 52)) +   labs(x = "Week", y = NULL, title = "Weekly HAI intensity",        caption = "Figure 2: Weekly HAI intensity by week and year (cases per week by infection type).") +   facet_wrap(~ yr, ncol = 2, scales = "free_x") +   theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +   theme(legend.position = "right", plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"))

title: Examples: Interactive Charts
text: According Figure 3, male counts surpass female counts across HAI categories metrics regions, gap marked UTI BSI, indicating consistently higher burden among male patients. EU/EEA shows wider male female differences deaths BSI SSI, Germany exhibits clearer divergence DALYs HAP BSI, suggesting variation severity profiles regions. CDI remains smallest contributor sexes regions, yet maintains stable pattern minimal sex disparity, highlighting comparatively lower overall impact.
code: # Male and Female gap by HAI, split by region sex_agg <- sim_monthly |>   group_by(region, hai, sex) |>   summarise(     cases  = sum(cases_month),     deaths = sum(deaths_month),     dalys  = sum(dalys_month),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   tidyr::pivot_longer(     c(cases, deaths, dalys),     names_to = "metric", values_to = "value"   ) |>   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = sex, values_from = value) |>   filter(!is.na(Female), !is.na(Male))  ggplot(sex_agg, aes(x = Female, xend = Male, y = hai)) +   geom_segment(linewidth = 0.8, aes(yend = hai), colour = "grey60") +   geom_point(size = 2.6, colour = "#1f77b4") +          # Female   geom_point(aes(x = Male), size = 2.6, colour = "#d62728") +  # Male   scale_x_continuous(     labels = scales::label_number(scale = 1e-3, suffix = "K"),     expand = expansion(mult = c(0.02, 0.06))   ) +   labs(     x = "Count (K)",     y = NULL,     title = "Male and Female gap by HAI",     caption = "Figure 3: Male and Female gap by HAI (faceted by region and metric)."   ) +   facet_grid(region ~ metric, scales = "free_x") +   theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +   theme(     plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),     strip.text = element_text(face = "bold")   )

what: Daily Distribution HAI (Violin and Jitter Chart)
title: Examples: Interactive Charts
text: According Figure 4, daily case distributions reveal UTI significant burden among HAIS EU/EEA Germany, consistently higher medians notably wider variation, indicating larger volumes greater variability day day. HAP SSI show moderate yet stable daily ranges, BSI CDI remain closely clustered low dispersion, reflecting smaller predictable daily burdens. Notably, EU/EEA exhibits slightly broader distribution UTI compared Germany, suggesting marginally higher volatility daily case counts regional level.
code: daily_region <- sim_daily |>   group_by(date, hai, region) |>   summarise(cases = sum(cases_day), .groups = "drop")  ggplot(daily_region, aes(x = hai, y = cases)) +   geom_violin(fill = "grey90", colour = "grey60", scale = "width", trim = TRUE) +   geom_jitter(width = 0.15, height = 0, alpha = 0.25, size = 0.9) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::label_comma()) +   labs(x = "HAI", y = "Daily cases", title = "Daily distribution by HAI",        caption = "Figure 4: Male and Female gap by HAI (faceted by region and metric).") +   facet_wrap(~ region) +   theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +   theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),         strip.text = element_text(face = "bold"))

title: Get started with yusufHAIGermany
text: package provides three simulation tables HAIs Germany (2011 – 2012) cleaned get formats: sim_monthly: date, year, month, hai, region, sex, cases_month, deaths_month, dalys_month. sim_weekly: date, year, iso_week, hai, region, sex, cases_week, deaths_week, dalys_week. sim_daily: date, year, yday, wday, hai, region, sex, cases_day, deaths_day, dalys_day. details data source variable definitions, see articles/data-description.html, examples common analysis steps provided articles/examples.html.
code: #load the datasets from the installed package during vignette build if (!requireNamespace("yusufHAIGermany", quietly = TRUE)) {   stop("Package not available in vignette build process.") }  data("sim_monthly", package = "yusufHAIGermany") data("sim_weekly",  package = "yusufHAIGermany") data("sim_daily",   package = "yusufHAIGermany")  #quick sanity check so the build fails early if something is missing stopifnot(   exists("sim_monthly"), exists("sim_weekly"), exists("sim_daily") )

title: Get started with yusufHAIGermany
text: glimpse() function helps understand data type appearance, making process easier IDA EDA.

title: Get started with yusufHAIGermany
text: hese example tables figures can used start analysing data: Summary table year, region, metric, HAI Summary year, region, metric, HAI categories columns. According Table 1, Germany consistently reports higher case counts overall EU/EEA, UTI HAP making largest portions years. DALYs follow similar pattern, showing burden driven frequency severity categories. Deaths remain significantly lower across groups, distribution across HAI types reflects patterns seen cases DALYs. Summary year, sex, metric, HAI categories columns. According Table 2, male patients consistently show higher case counts DALYs across HAI categories, reflecting greater infection burden compared females years. distribution across HAP, SSI, BSI, UTI, CDI remains stable sexes, indicating similar clinical patterns despite differences overall magnitude. Deaths follow trend, male totals slightly exceeding female totals across HAI types. Monthly Total HAI cases Composition Infection Monthly total HAI cases composition infection type, 2011–2012 According Figure 1, total HAI cases remained high throughout 2011 – 2012, noticeable peak mid-2011. UTI consistently made largest share monthly burden, CDI contributed smallest proportion. overall pattern remains stable, seasonal increases decreases seem consistent across infection types. information regarding analysis, please check live Shiny dashboard App articles/examples.html.
code: # HAI categories hai_levels <- sort(unique(sim_monthly$hai))  # Build table for each metric summary_region <- sim_monthly |>   group_by(year, region, hai) |>   summarise(     cases  = sum(cases_month),     deaths = sum(deaths_month),     dalys  = sum(dalys_month),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   pivot_longer(cols = c(cases, deaths, dalys),                names_to = "metric",                values_to = "value") |>   pivot_wider(     names_from = hai,     values_from = value,     values_fill = 0   ) |>   arrange(year, region, metric)  knitr::kable(   summary_region,   caption = "Summary by year, region, and metric, with HAI categories as columns." ) summary_sex <- sim_monthly |>   group_by(year, sex, hai) |>   summarise(     cases  = sum(cases_month),     deaths = sum(deaths_month),     dalys  = sum(dalys_month),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   pivot_longer(cols = c(cases, deaths, dalys),                names_to = "metric",                values_to = "value") |>   pivot_wider(     names_from = hai,     values_from = value,     values_fill = 0   ) |>   arrange(year, sex, metric)  knitr::kable(   summary_sex,   caption = "Summary by year, sex, and metric, with HAI categories as columns." ) monthly_totals <- sim_monthly |>   dplyr::group_by(date) |>   dplyr::summarise(total_cases = sum(cases_month), .groups = "drop")  monthly_mix <- sim_monthly |>   dplyr::group_by(date, hai) |>   dplyr::summarise(cases = sum(cases_month), .groups = "drop")  peak_pt <- monthly_totals |> dplyr::slice_max(total_cases, n = 1)  ggplot() +   geom_area(data = monthly_mix,             aes(x = as.Date(date), y = cases, fill = hai), alpha = 0.75) +   geom_line(data = monthly_totals,             aes(x = as.Date(date), y = total_cases), linewidth = 1.1) +   geom_point(data = peak_pt,              aes(x = as.Date(date), y = total_cases), size = 2) +   geom_text(data = peak_pt,             aes(x = as.Date(date), y = total_cases,                 label = scales::comma(total_cases)),             vjust = -0.5, size = 3.2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::label_comma()) +   labs(x = "Date", y = "Cases (monthly)",        fill = "Infection type",        title = "Monthly HAI burden: Total and Composition") +   theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +   theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),         legend.position = "bottom")

title: Get started with yusufHAIGermany
text: package : Built : shiny bslib: UI components theming interactive apps. ggplot2 plotly: Static interactive charts EDA review. dplyr, tidyr, lubridate, scales, glue: Data wrangling, date handling, formatting, text utilities. yusufHAIGermany: Package datasets helpers. Developed : devtools, usethis: Package scaffolding, workflow, checks. roxygen2: -source documentation NAMESPACE generation. pkgdown: Static documentation site functions, articles, examples. knitr, rmarkdown: Reproducible vignettes literate programming. rsconnect: Deployment shinyapps.io.

title: Analysis of Germany HAI Burden (German PPS) with Shiny Explorer
text: yusufHAIGermany R package offers reproducible simulation visualisation framework examining Healthcare-Associated Infections (HAIs) Germany. inspired Eurosurveillance study Zacher et al. (2019).“Application new methodology R package reveals high burden healthcare-associated infections (HAI) Germany compared average European Union/European Economic Area, 2011 – 2012.” package generates daily, weekly, monthly simulated datasets calibrated 2011 – 2012 ECDC PPS (Point Prevalence Survey) data. package can accessed online, website explaining , shiny dashboard can reached via App menu. link access : https://etc5523-2025.github.io/assignment-4-packages--shiny-apps-yusufkurniar01/

(2019).Application new methodology R package reveals high burden healthcare-associated infections (HAI) Germany compared average European Union/European Economic Area, 2011–2012.Eurosurveillance, 24(46). https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.46.1900135 Data licensed Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 (CC 4.0).

code: library(yusufHAIGermany)  # Explore simulated monthly data head(sim_monthly)  # Summarise DALYs by infection type library(dplyr) sim_monthly |>   group_by(hai) |>   summarise(total_dalys = sum(dalys))

title: Analysis of Germany HAI Burden (German PPS) with Shiny Explorer
text: Full documentation provided four articles: Data description — original PPS source three simulated tables; variables, units, structure. See: articles/data-description.html Get started: required libraries, cleaning simulation overview, quick tour data. See: articles/get-started.html Examples: practical recipes filter, aggregate, plot data analysis. See: articles/examples.html Germany HAI explorer: short analytical summary HAI Germany project link Shiny app. See: articles/germany-hai-explorer.html browse locally R:
code: browseVignettes("yusufHAIGermany")  # or open directly: vignette("data-description", package = "yusufHAIGermany") vignette("examples", package = "yusufHAIGermany") vignette("germany-HAI-explorer", package = "yusufHAIGermany") vignette("get-started", package = "yusufHAIGermany")

what: Simulated German HAI daily series, 2011–2012 — sim_daily
title: Simulated German HAI daily series, 2011–2012 — sim_daily
text: Synthetic daily counts DALYs HAI type, split region sex.

title: Simulated German HAI daily series, 2011–2012 — sim_daily
Simulated German HAI daily series, 2011–2012 — sim_daily
text: tibble columns: date Date year Integer year yday Day--year 1 366 wday Day--week 1 = Mon 7 = Sun hai Character infection type region Character region label sex Character sex label: "Female" "Male" cases_day Integer simulated cases deaths_day Integer simulated deaths dalys_day Numeric simulated DALYs

what: Simulated German HAI monthly series, 2011–2012 — sim_monthly
title: Simulated German HAI monthly series, 2011–2012 — sim_monthly
text: Synthetic monthly counts DALYs HAI type (HAP, SSI, BSI, UTI, CDI), split region sex.

title: Simulated German HAI monthly series, 2011–2012 — sim_monthly
Simulated German HAI monthly series, 2011–2012 — sim_monthly
text: tibble columns: date Date, first day month year Integer year month Integer month number hai Character infection type region Character region label sex Character sex label: "Female" "Male" cases_month Integer simulated cases deaths_month Integer simulated deaths dalys_month Numeric simulated DALYs

title: Simulated German HAI weekly series, 2011–2012 — sim_weekly
Simulated German HAI weekly series, 2011–2012 — sim_weekly
text: tibble columns: date Date ISO week start (Monday) year Integer year iso_week Integer ISO week number hai Character infection type region Character region label sex Character sex label: "Female" "Male" cases_week Integer simulated cases deaths_week Integer simulated deaths dalys_week Numeric simulated DALYs
